cover.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to put something over or be over something in order to hide, close, or protect it
cover.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Cover the pot and bake for an hour.
She wore a low-cut dress, partly covered by a thin shawl.
Dan covered his face with his hands.
cover.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if something covers a surface, it forms a layer over it
cover.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Much of the country is covered by snow.
The bulletin board was covered with messages.
The eruption of the volcano covered states as far away as Montana in a fine layer of ash.
cover.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to include or deal with a particular subject or group of things
cover.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Are there any areas you feel are not covered adequately in the book?
‘Exercise’ is a word which covers a vast range of activities.
We need more time to cover so much ground (=include so many things).
pollutants that are not covered by the Kyoto agreement
cover.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: They were hoping to cover 40 miles yesterday.
A leopard can cover a lot of ground very quickly.
cover.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to report the details of an event for a newspaper or a television or radio programme
cover.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: I’d just returned from covering the Cambodian war.
cover.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: if a sum of money covers the cost of something, it is enough to pay for it
cover.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: The award should be enough to cover her tuition fees.
Airlines are raising fares to cover the rising costs of fuel.
cover.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: if your insurance covers you or your possessions, it promises to pay you money if you have an accident, something is stolen etc
cover.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: Most policies cover accidental damage to pipes.
The treatment wasn’t covered by her health care insurance.
He thought he was covered to drive the vehicle.
cover.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: to protect someone by being ready to shoot anyone who attacks them
cover.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: I’ll make for the door – cover me, will you?
cover.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: to aim a gun at a person or a place where people might be, in order to prevent them from moving or escaping
cover.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: He stepped into the doorway and swung the gun up to cover the corridor.
cover.translation[0].definitions[10].def: to stay close to a member of the opposing team or a part of the field in order to prevent your opponents from gaining points
cover.translation[0].definitions[11].def: to perform or record a song that was originally recorded by another artist
cover.translation[0].definitions[11].exa: They’ve covered several hits from the 1980s.
cover.translation[0].note_box[0].section: to put something over, on, or around something else, to hide it, protect it, or improve its appearance
Cover the dough, and leave it to rise.
She wears a lot of make-up to cover her spots.
to put a cloth, blanket etc loosely over the top of something in order to cover it
They gave him a blanket to put over his legs.
to put paper, plastic, cloth etc tightly around something in order to protect, decorate, or post it
I haven’t wrapped her birthday present yet.
to surround something completely so that it is difficult to see – used especially about darkness, smoke, and clouds
At sunset, darkness enveloped the town.
to be covered and hidden in mist, smoke etc
The mountains were shrouded in mist.
cover.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: something that is put on top of something else to protect it
cover.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: A dust cover (=to keep dirt etc off) hung over the painting.
cover.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: the outer front or back part of a magazine, book etc
cover.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: His photo’s on the cover of ‘Newsweek’ again.
I read the magazine from cover to cover (=all of it).
an advertisement on the back cover
The cover shot was of three guys in army kit.
cover.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: shelter or protection from bad weather or attack
cover.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: We were forced to take cover in a barn.
Three soldiers broke cover (=left the place where they were hiding).
He was shot in the head as he ran for cover.
cover.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: the protection insurance gives you, so that it pays you money if you are injured, something is stolen etc
cover.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: military protection and support given to aircraft, ships etc that are likely to be attacked
cover.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: fighters used as cover for ground troops
cover.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: trees and plants that grow in large numbers on a piece of land
cover.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: Once the forest cover is felled, rains wash away the soil.
With its spreading stems, ivy makes good ground cover.
cover.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: clouds, snow etc that partly hide the sky or the ground
cover.translation[1].definitions[6].exam: Cloud cover in the morning should clear later.
cover.translation[1].definitions[7].defi: an arrangement in which people do a job or provide a service, especially because the people who normally do it are not there
cover.translation[1].definitions[7].exam: It’s your responsibility to arrange adequate cover for holiday periods.
cover.translation[1].definitions[8].defi: a new recording of a song, piece of music etc that was originally recorded by a different artist
cover.translation[1].definitions[8].exam: She’s opted to do a cover version for her first single.
cover.translation[1].definitions[9].defi: behaviour or activities that seem normal or honest but are being used to hide something bad or illegal
cover.translation[1].definitions[9].exam: The gang used the shop as a cover for drug deals.
All that toughness is just a cover for his inability to show affection.
cover.translation[1].note_box[0].section: The price of the book is on the back cover.
I never buy books in hard cover – they’re much more expensive.
There was a blonde girl on the magazine cover.
Last month’s cover story was entitled ‘Your Child’s Brain’.
The picture became the July 4th cover shot.
the cover design of the Christmas issue
She had always liked the idea of being a cover girl.
read something from cover to cover
He read it from cover to cover in less than three hours.
cover.translation[1].note_box[1].section: cover
something that is put on or over something else to protect it, for example a piece of metal, plastic, or glass
a manhole cover
the cover that goes over the barbecue
covering
a layer of something, or a sheet of something, that covers something else
There was light covering of snow on the ground.
The hard shell acts as a protective covering.
the cloth coverings on the altar
lid
a cover for a container such as a pan or a box
the lid of the box
a saucepan lid
top/cap
the thing that you put on top of a bottle, tube, or pen, in order to prevent the liquid or other things inside from coming out
I can’t find the cap for the pen.
Put the top back on the milk!
the cap that goes on the toothpaste
cork
the top part that you put on top of a bottle of wine
Can you take off the cork for me?
wrapping
a sheet of paper, plastic etc that is put around something in order to cover or protect it
John tore the wrapping off his presents.
The lamp was still in its wrapping.
wrapper
a piece of paper or plastic that is put around something you buy, especially a small object
Put the candy wrappers in your pocket.
He took the drinking straw out of its wrapper.
cover.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: insurance against losing something or suffering damage, injury etc
cover.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The policies provide cover for death of the policyholder.
You have to pay an extra premium to have insurance cover on your personal possessions.
cover.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: the value that someone or something is insured for
cover.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: insurance cover of up to £5000 per item for loss or damage
cover.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: something valuable, for example property or an insurance policy, that you promise to give to a bank or someone who has lent you money if you fail to pay the money back
cover.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: the amount of notes and coins kept by a bank to meet the needs of its customers
cover.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: when an insurance policy covers someone or something, the insurance company will pay out money if the person dies or is injured, or if something is damaged, stolen etc
cover.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: You are not covered by your medical insurance if an accident happens abroad.
Our optional Payment Protector plan covers you against loss of income in the event of sickness, accident or compulsory redundancy.
cover.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: if an amount of money covers something, it is enough to pay for it
cover.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: It took a massive $1.68 billion pretax charge to cover losses from bad loans.
cover.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: if an institution covers a loan, it makes sure that it has something valuable, for example property or an insurance policy, that it can keep if the loan is not repaid
cover.translation[3].definitions[2].exam: Many of these banks’ loans no longer have collateral that covers the amount of the loan.
cover.translation[3].definitions[3].defi: to obtain and pay for a currency, bonds, shares etc that are needed to make a sale that has been agreed, for example in a FUTURES CONTRACT
cover.translation[3].definitions[3].exam: The price of zinc for immediate delivery rose sharply because Chinese zinc producers that had sold short had to cover their positions.
